message_1: Let X be the topological space obtained by identifying the boundary of the unit square $[0,1]\times[0,1]$ to a point, i.e., $X=(S^1\times [0,1])/((x,0)\sim (x,1)\text{ and }(0,y)\sim(1,y))$, and let $f:S^1\rightarrow X$ be the map that sends each point of the circle $S^1$ to the corresponding equivalence class in X under the identification. Calculate the fundamental group $\pi_1(X,f(\ast))$ of X based at the point $f(\ast)$.
message_2:
To compute the fundamental group of X, we will use the Seifert-van Kampen theorem. First, we need to choose two open sets U and V such that their union covers X, and their intersection is simply connected.

Let U be the interior of the square $[0,1]\times[0,1]$ along with a small neighborhood of the boundary, and let V be a small neighborhood of the identified boundary point in X. Then, U is homeomorphic to an open disk, and V is homeomorphic to an open cylinder. Their intersection U ∩ V is homeomorphic to an annulus, which is simply connected.

Now, we can apply the Seifert-van Kampen theorem. Since U is homeomorphic to an open disk, its fundamental group is trivial, i.e., $\pi_1(U) = 0$. V is homeomorphic to an open cylinder, so its fundamental group is isomorphic to the fundamental group of a circle, i.e., $\pi_1(V) \cong \mathbb{Z}$. The intersection U ∩ V is simply connected, so its fundamental group is trivial, i.e., $\pi_1(U ∩ V) = 0$.

According to the Seifert-van Kampen theorem, the fundamental group of X is the free product of the fundamental groups of U and V, with the fundamental group of their intersection factored out:

$\pi_1(X) \cong (\pi_1(U) * \pi_1(V)) / \pi_1(U ∩ V) \cong (0 * \mathbb{Z}) / 0 \cong \mathbb{Z}$.

So, the fundamental group of X based at the point $f(\ast)$ is isomorphic to the integers, i.e., $\pi_1(X, f(\ast)) \cong \mathbb{Z}$.
